questions.text: In hypersensitivity type 1, which of the following chemokines play a role in the recruitment of eosinophils to the site of reaction?
questions.solution:
B. Eotaxin plays a role in the recruitment of eosinophils to the site of reaction

In late phase reaction of type 1 HSR, leukocytes are recruited that amplify and sustain the inflammatory response without additional exposure to triggering antigen.

Eosinophils are often abundant leukocyte population in these reactions which are recruited to sites of immediate hypersensitivity by chemokines, such as EOTAXIN and others.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Fractalkine - Specific for monocyte.

Option C: IL - 8 - Specific for neutrophils.

Option D: MCP - 1 - Specific for monocyte.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Eotaxin plays a role in the recruitment of eosinophils to the site of reaction

Reference: ROBBINS AND COTRAN pathologic basics of disease, 10th Edition, Page Number:207.

questions.text: All of the following are the causes of noncaseating granuloma except?
questions.solution:
Histoplasmosis is a fungal infection which shows Caseating granuloma.

A caseous granuloma is a type of chronic inflammatory response characterized by a necrotic center (caseation) surrounded by immune cells. It is often associated with infections like tuberculosis (TB) caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

Histopathology:

  • Necrotic Core: The central area of a caseous granuloma contains necrotic tissue with a cheese-like (caseous) appearance, hence the name.
  • Macrophages: Around the core are activated macrophages, also known as epithelioid cells, which form a tight cluster.
  • Giant Cells: These are multinucleated cells formed by the fusion of macrophages, often seen at the periphery of the granuloma.
  • Lymphocytes: Surrounding the macrophages and giant cells are T-lymphocytes, which mediate the immune response.
  • Fibrosis: Over time, fibrous tissue may form around the granuloma as part of the healing process.

Caseous granulomas are most commonly associated with tuberculosis, but they can also occur in other conditions like fungal infections (e.g., histoplasmosis, coccidioidomycosis), syphilis, and sarcoidosis.

Mechanism:

The body forms granulomas as an attempt to contain and isolate pathogens that are difficult to eradicate, such as mycobacteria. T-helper cells (Th1) release interferon-gamma (IFN-γ), activating macrophages to form granulomas.

Incorrect Options:

Non-caseating granulomas are a type of granulomatous inflammation that lack central necrosis (caseation). These granulomas are typically seen in a variety of diseases, often of immune or inflammatory origin.

Options A,B & D: All are the examples of Non caseating granuloma.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Caseating granuloma is seen in histoplasmosis.

Reference: ROBBINS AND COTRAN pathologic basics of disease, 10th Edition, Page Number. 100.

questions.text: Which of the following is the reason for the Eosinophilic appearance of necrotic cells in H & E stain?
questions.solution:
Necrotic cells show increased eosinophilia in H & E stain which is attributable to loss of cytoplasmic RNA and due to accumulation of denatured cytoplasmic proteins which binds to red dye eosin.

Necrosis is a pathological event that is the consequence of severe injury.

Necrosis is characterized by

  • denaturation of cellular proteins
  • leakage of cellular contents through damaged membranes
  • local inflammation due to enzymatic digestion of lethally injured cells

Early Morphological changes in necrosis:

  • Increased eosinophilia
  • Glassy homogenous appearance (due to loss of glycogen)
  • Vacuolated cytoplasm (moth eaten appearance)

Reference: ROBBINS AND COTRAN pathologic basics of disease, 10th Edition, Page Number. 40.

questions.text: What is the term used for tissue death due to occlusion of arterial/venous supply?
questions.solution:
An infarction is an area of ischemic necrosis caused by occlusion of either the arterial supply or the venous drainage.

Infarcts are classified on the basis of their color. Thus, infarcts may be either red (hemorrhagic) or white (anemic) and may be either septic or bland.

Red infarcts with venous occlusions (such as in ovarian torsion); in loose tissues (e.g., lung) where blood can collect in infarcted zones; in tissues with dual circulations such as lung and small intestine, where partial, inadequate perfusion by collateral arterial supplies is typical; in previously congested tissues (as a consequence of sluggish venous outflow); and when flow is reestablished after infarction has occurred (e.g., after angioplasty of an arterial obstruction).

White infarcts occur with arterial occlusions in solid organs with end-arterial circulations (e.g., heart, spleen, and kidney), and where tissue density limits the seepage of blood from adjoining patent vascular beds . Infarcts tend to be wedge-shaped, with the occluded vessel at the apex and the organ periphery forming the base.

Option B: Necrosis is a pathological event that is the consequence of severe injury.

Necrosis is characterized by

  • denaturation of cellular proteins
  • leakage of cellular contents through damaged membranes
  • local inflammation
  • enzymatic digestion of lethally injured cells.

Option C: Apoptosis is a type of cell death that is induced by a tightly regulated suicide program in which cells destined to die activate intrinsic enzymes that degrade the cell's genomic DNA and nuclear and cytoplasmic proteins.

Option D: Abnormalities that lead to Thrombosis are (VIRCHOW TRIAD)

  1. Endothelial injury
  2. Stasis of turbulent flow
  3. Hypercoagulability of the blood

Reference: ROBBINS AND COTRAN pathologic basics of disease, 10th Edition, Page Number. 133.

questions.text: Which is an example of Pro apoptotic body?
questions.solution:
Apoptosis is a form of programmed cell death that occurs in a controlled, regulated manner, allowing the body to remove damaged, unwanted, or harmful cells without causing an inflammatory response. It plays a crucial role in maintaining tissue homeostasis, development, and immune function.

Key Features:

  1. Cell Shrinkage: Cells shrink and condense while the organelles remain intact.
  2. Chromatin Condensation: DNA condenses and fragments within the nucleus.
  3. Membrane Blebbing: The cell membrane forms bubble-like protrusions called blebs.
  4. Formation of Apoptotic Bodies: The cell fragments into smaller vesicles that are engulfed by macrophages or neighbouring cells.
  5. No Inflammation: Since the cell contents are not spilled into the surrounding tissue, apoptosis does not trigger an inflammatory response.

Mechanism:

  1. Intrinsic Pathway: Triggered by internal signals such as DNA damage, mitochondrial dysfunction, or oxidative stress.
    • Involves activation of mitochondria and release of cytochrome c, leading to caspase activation (proteolytic enzymes).
  2. Extrinsic Pathway: Initiated by external signals like binding of death ligands (e.g., Fas ligand) to death receptors on the cell surface.
    • Also leads to caspase activation, resulting in the dismantling of cellular components.

Option D: Pro apoptotic bodies: Cytochrome C, BAX AND BAK

Option A, B: Anti-apoptotic bodies: BCL 2, BCL X1, and MCL 1

Option C: Regulated apoptosis initiators: BAD, BIM , BID, Puma, Noxa

Reference: ROBBINS & COTRAN pathologic basics of disease, 10th Edition Page Number. 45.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman comes to an OPD with hypertension, weight gain, pinkish purple striae on her abdomen and hirsutism. Which of the following malignancy is most likely to occur in this patient?
questions.solution:
• Given scenario suggests that the patient is having CUSHING
  • It is caused by excessive production of CORTICOTROPIN(ACTH).
  • Endocrinopathies are frequently encountered paraneoplastic syndromes.
  • Approximately 50% of affected individuals have carcinoma of the lung, small cell type.

Small cell cancer is an aggressive type of cancer that primarily originates in the lungs. It is characterized by small, round, rapidly growing cancer cells showing salt and pepper appearance along with Azzopardi effect (Basophilic staining of the walls)

Option A: Ovarian carcinoma is most commonly associated with hypoglycemia.

Option B: Breast carcinoma is most commonly associated with hypercalcemia, dermatomyositis.

Option C: Squamous cell carcinoma of lung is most commonly associated with hypercalcemia.

Reference: ROBBINS & COTRAN pathologic basics of disease, 10th Edition, Page Number. 329.

questions.text: Match the following disorders with inheritance pattern:
questions.solution: Reference: ROBBINS & COTRAN pathologic basics of disease, 10th Edition, Page Number. 145,146.

choices.text: To promote cell division and growth
To inhibit cell division and growth

questions.text: What is primary function of RB gene?
questions.solution:
The RB gene is a tumor suppressor gene that encodes a protein that regulates cell cycle progression.

  • It prevents excessive cell growth by inhibiting the transition from the G1 phase to the S phase of the cell cycle.
  • It is also known as Governor of proliferation.

A: Promoting cell division and growth is the opposite of the RB gene's function.

Option C: DNA repair is not the primary function of the RB gene.

Option D: While the RB gene can influence apoptosis, its primary function is to regulate cell cycle progression.

Reference: ROBBINS & COTRAN pathologic basics of disease, 10th Edition, Page Number. 293.

questions.text: What is the correct sequence of cellular events in acute inflammation?
questions.solution:
The cellular events in acute inflammation are as follows:

  1. Vasodilation: Increased blood flow to the affected area.
  2. Emigration: Leukocytes (white blood cells) migrate out of blood vessels into the tissue.
  3. Chemotaxis: Leukocytes move towards chemical signals (chemokines) released by damaged cells or pathogens.
  4. Phagocytosis: Leukocytes engulf and digest foreign particles, bacteria, or dead cells.

Reference: ROBBINS & COTRAN pathologic basics of disease, 10th Edition, Page Number. 77.

questions.text: A 65 year old patient on dialysis, kidney biopsy showing amyloid deposits in glomeruli and tubule interstitium. Which of the following precursor protein is responsible?
questions.solution:
Option A: Dialysis-related amyloidosis: Elevated β2M levels due to chronic kidney disease and long-term hemodialysis.

Option B: β2-transferrin is a glycoprotein, consisting of two polypeptide chains (β1 and β2) and two carbohydrate chains.

  • Function: It binds to iron and transports it from the intestine to the liver, spleen, and bone marrow.

Option C: β2 glycoprotein is a protein found in the blood that plays a role in blood clotting and the immune system.

Abnormalities in β2 glycoprotein have been linked to various conditions, including:

  • Antiphospholipid syndrome (APS)
  • Thrombosis
  • Recurrent miscarriage
  • Lupus

Option D: Transthyretin (TTR) is a transport protein that carries thyroid hormones and vitamin A in the blood.

  • It's produced mainly in the liver and plays a crucial role in transporting these essential nutrients to various tissues and organs.
  • Abnormal TTR levels or function are associated with certain diseases, such as:
    • Familial amyloid polyneuropathy (FAP)
    • Familial amyloid cardiomyopathy (FAC)
    • Senile systemic amyloidosis (SSA)
  • These conditions often result from TTR misfolding and aggregation, leading to amyloid deposits in tissues.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Dialysis-related amyloidosis: Elevated β2M levels due to chronic kidney disease and long-term hemodialysis.

Reference: ROBBINS & COTRAN pathologic basics of disease, 10th Edition, Page Number. 261.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female has Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. Myocardial biopsy showing lipofuscin accumulation in cardiomyocytes. What is the underlying mechanism?
questions.solution:
Oxidative stress and lipid peroxidation:

  • Lipofuscin accumulation in cardiomyocytes is a hallmark of oxidative stress.
  • Lipid peroxidation results in the formation of reactive aldehydes, which cross-link proteins and lipids, forming
  • Oxidative stress contributes to cellular damage and dysfunction in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.

Appears as yellow-brown, finely granular intracytoplasmic, often perinuclear pigment.

Lipofuscin accumulation in the heart muscle as process of ageing is called "Brown atrophy of heart"

  • This mechanism is supported by studies showing increased oxidative stress markers in patients with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.

Option A: Mitochondrial dysfunction and ATP depletion:

  • Mitochondrial dysfunction can contribute to cardiomyopathy.
  • ATP depletion can lead to cellular damage and dysfunction.
  • Mitochondrial dysfunction may contribute to oxidative stress, but it's not the primary mechanism for lipofuscin formation.

Option C: Inflammatory response and cytokine release:

  • Inflammation plays a role in cardiomyopathy pathogenesis.
  • Cytokine release contributes to inflammation and tissue damage.
  • Inflammation may contribute to oxidative stress, but it's not the primary mechanism for lipofuscin formation.

Option D: Genetic mutation and telomere shortening:

  • Genetic mutations can contribute to hypertrophic cardiomyopathy susceptibility.
  • Telomere shortening is associated with aging and cellular senescence.
  • Genetic mutations may contribute to mitochondrial dysfunction or oxidative stress, but it's not the primary mechanism for lipofuscin formation.

Reference: ROBBINS AND COTRAN pathologic basics of disease, 10th Edition, Page Number. 68.

questions.text: What is the role of transforming growth factor-beta (TGF-β) in scar formation?
questions.solution:
Transforming growth factor-beta (TGF-β) plays a crucial role in scar formation by: Stimulating fibroblast proliferation:

  • TGF-β promotes the growth and differentiation of fibroblasts, leading to increased collagen production.
  • Enhancing collagen synthesis: TGF-β stimulates the production of collagen types I and III, essential for scar tissue formation.
  • Regulating extracellular matrix (ECM) deposition: TGF-β influences the organization and cross-linking of collagen fibers, affecting scar strength and architecture.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: TGF-β has anti-inflammatory effects, reducing inflammation and promoting tissue repair.

Option B: TGF-β stimulates the production of collagen.

Option D: TGF-β actually stimulates scar contraction by promoting fibroblast-to-myofibroblast differentiation and increasing contractile forces.

Reference: ROBBINS AND COTRAN pathologic basics of disease, 10th Edition, Page Number. 104.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female with Fragile X syndrome presents with Premature ovarian failure, Cognitive impairment, Mood instability. What is the underlying mechanism?
questions.solution:
The underlying mechanism of Fragile X syndrome is the expansion of the CGG repeat in the FMR1 gene, leading to:

  1. Silencing of the FMR1 gene
  2. Loss of FMRP (Fragile X Mental Retardation Protein)
  3. Disrupted synaptic plasticity and neuronal function
    • Premature ovarian failure (POF) is a common feature in female carriers of the FMR1 gene expansion, affecting up to 20% of carriers.

FMR1 gene expansion consequences:

  • Loss of FMRP leads to disrupted synaptic plasticity and neuronal function.
  • FMRP regulates mRNA translation and synaptic protein expression.
  • FMR1 gene expansion affects various tissues, including ovaries, brain, and heart.

Option B: X-chromosome deletion - Associated with different genetic disorders (e.g., Turner syndrome)

Option C: Hormonal imbalance:

  • May contribute to mood instability, but not the primary cause.
  • Not directly related to FMR1 gene expansion.

Option D: Mitochondrial dysfunction- Associated with different neurodegenerative disorders (e.g., mitochondrial myopathies)

KEY TAKEAWAYS: The underlying mechanism of Fragile X syndrome is the expansion of the CGG repeat in the FMR1 gene, leading to:

  1. Silencing of the FMR1 gene
  2. Loss of FMRP (Fragile X Mental Retardation Protein)
  3. Disrupted synaptic plasticity and neuronal function

Reference: ROBBINS AND COTRAN pathologic basics of disease, 10th Edition, Page Number. 174.

questions.text: What is the role of complement in Type 3 hypersensitivity?
questions.solution:
In Type 3 hypersensitivity, complement plays a crucial role in amplifying inflammation by:

  1. Immune complex deposition activates complement.
  2. Complement components (C3a, C5a) attract and activate neutrophils.
  3. Neutrophils release pro-inflammatory mediators, exacerbating inflammation.
  4. Complement-mediated inflammation leads to tissue damage.

Option A: Activation of mast cells - Relevant to Type 1 hypersensitivity (allergic reactions).

Option B. Opsonization of pathogens:

  • Complement helps opsonize pathogens for phagocytosis.
  • Not have a role in type 3 hypersensitivity.

Option C: Clearance of immune complexes:

  • Complement helps solubilize and clear immune complexes
  • However, in Type 3 hypersensitivity, immune complexes deposit in tissues, causing inflammation.
  • Complement components involved:
    • C1q: binds to immune complexes, activating complement cascade
    • C3a, C5a: anaphylatoxins, attracting neutrophils and amplifying inflammation
    • C5b-9: membrane attack complex, forming pores in cell membranes

Reference: ROBBINS & COTRAN pathologic basics of disease, 10th Edition, Page Number. 212.

questions.text: What is the role of EMT in cancer progression?
questions.solution:
Epithelial-Mesenchymal Transition (EMT) plays a crucial role in cancer progression by:

  1. Enabling cancer cells to acquire a mesenchymal phenotype.
  2. Losing cell-cell adhesion and gaining migratory properties.
  3. Invading surrounding tissues and blood vessels.
  4. Metastasizing to distant organs.

EMT promotes cancer progression by:

  • Enhancing cell migration and invasion.
  • Increasing resistance to apoptosis.
  • Facilitating angiogenesis.
  • Promoting cancer stem cell maintenance.

Clinical significance:

  • EMT is associated with poor prognosis and reduced survival.
  • EMT markers (e.g., Twist, Snail) are used as prognostic indicators.
  • Targeting EMT pathways is a potential therapeutic strategy.

Option A: Enhances cell differentiation:

  • EMT actually reduces cell differentiation.
  • Cancer cells become less differentiated and more aggressive.

Option B: Increases cell adhesion:

  • EMT reduces cell-cell adhesion.
  • Cancer cells become more migratory and invasive.

Option D: Inhibits angiogenesis:

  • EMT actually promotes
  • Cancer cells secrete pro-angiogenic factors.

Reference: ROBBINS & COTRAN pathologic basics of disease, 10th Edition, Page Number. 307.
